parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "Slurm",
  "details": {
    "job_name": "job-dali-lustre",
    "output_file": "job-dali-lustre.o%j",
    "error_file": "job-dali-lustre.e%j",
    "queue": "rtx",
    "nodes": 1,
    "tasks": 1,
    "time": "48:00:00",
    "root_dir": "${HOME}/maypaper",
    "repo": "thesis",
    "workspace": "${ROOT_DIR}/$REPO",
    "data": "/scratch1/07854/dantas/shared",
    "gcc_version": "8.3.0",
    "cuda_version": "10.1",
    "cudnn_version": "7.6.5",
    "nccl_version": "2.4.8-1",
    "openmpi_version": "2.1.6",
    "epochs": 3,
    "batch_size": 256,
    "dataset": "${DATA}/imagenet_processed/100g_tfrecords",
    "index": "${DATA}/idx_files/100g_tfrecords_idx",
    "target_dir": "${ROOT_DIR}/results/pytorch/june",
    "monarch_configs_path": "${HOME}/maypaper/thesis/configurations/frontera/tf_placement_100g_disk.yaml",
    "workers": 16,
    "models": ["lenet", "resnet50", "alexnet"]
  }
}
```

This script appears to be running on the Slurm workload manager. It is a serial job that utilizes the RTX queue. It loads several modules, including gcc, cuda, cudnn, nccl, and openmpi, along with the remora workload manager. The script then runs training jobs for three different models (lenet, resnet50, and alexnet) using a specified dataset, batch size, and epoch count. It uses the remora workload manager to launch these training jobs. It also uses the `/dev/shm`  filesystem for temporary storage. The script utilizes a dedicated configuration file for Monarch, a distributed deep learning framework.
